tables.table_title: Table 4 shows mean best solution values, standard deviations, standard error on the mean and $95 \%$ and $99 \%$ confidence intervals for each algorithm at generation 200 (convergence) when M is 50 (i.e. no initialisation control). In Table 5 we make a statistical comparison of performance at generations 100 and 200 using a Wilcoxon rank-sum test. At generation 100, there is no significant difference in the mean fitness of the best solutions found by DEUM $_{d}$ and TInSSel, at a $95 \%$ confidence level. DEUM $_{d}$ does however outperform CalEB and UC GA in terms of fitness. However, the schedules generated by TInSSel at this stage are more practical. At convergence (generation 200), with no initialisation control, DEUM $_{\mathrm{d}}$ significantly outperforms all of the other approaches.
